APHIDS, SCOURGE OF THE GARDEN 

   (For release Sun., Sept. 20)  
(JT) 
 By CASS PETERSON   
 c.1998 N.Y. Times News Service   

   The first sign of trouble is an oddly shaped leaf. It's twisted,
and puckered like seersucker, and I know before lifting it to check
the underside what I'm going to find there. Aphids.

   Among the insects that plague a garden, the aphid has no equal.
Old-timers call them plant lice, an appropriate sobriquet. A
gardener's life would be easier, nay, blissful, if it weren't for
the lousy aphids.

   Aphids suck the life out of plants. They feed on the sap, and
the penetrating mouthparts of a cluster of aphids are what cause
the leaves to become distorted. They can transmit viral diseases
from one plant to another. They excrete sugars from the plant
fluids, which encourage sooty mold, causing the black residue that
often spots the leaves of an aphid-infested plant.

   It's possible to avoid some insect pests simply by not growing
their favorite plants. I don't, for example, grow China asters
because I can't tolerate the black blister beetle. No such luck
with aphids. There are practically as many species of aphids as
there are plants for them to plague.

   The slate-blue aphids on nasturtiums are bean aphids, the
whitish-green ones on kale are cabbage aphids, and the pale green
ones on practically everything are green peach aphids.
Chrysanthemums have their own aphid species, fat and
chocolate-brown. The one that goes after crape myrtle will dine on
nothing else, but the one known as cotton or melon aphid will
attack a wide range of plants, from cucumbers to roses.

   They may be black, yellow, orange or rose-colored,
matte-finished or attractively iridescent, like mother-of-pearl.
But the only thing to admire, albeit grudgingly, about aphids is
their efficiency at being a scourge, a role for which they were
brilliantly designed by nature.

   Their soft bodies contain little other than a digestive system
and a reproductive system. They do nothing but eat and give birth.
They don't have muscles to speak of; they can barely walk. They
only develop wings if the population gets so overcrowded that they
need to fly off to a new food source.

   That can happen pretty quickly. From the time they appear in the
spring, and through most of the year, aphids are all female, and
they reproduce parthenogenetically _ that is, without benefit of
sex. Moreover, aphids bear their young live, rather than laying
eggs that might be vulnerable to predators. An adult aphid gives
birth every single day of its two- to three-week life span, and the
births are always multiple, triplets to sextuplets.

   The young are all female as well, of course. They emerge
ravenously hungry, and they start producing their own young in less
than a week. The embryos that will become a mother aphid's
daughters start to develop in her before she is even born, and
those embryos contain the developing embryos of her granddaughters.

   Aphids are fantastically, formidably fecund.

   Only in the late fall do male aphids appear, and then only
because the insect must lay eggs that will live over the winter to
become next season's aphid infestation. Thus, controlling aphids is
most critical in the fall. Every aphid sent to its reward in
September is a million aphids that won't be around to infest the
peppers next spring.

   Fortunately, gardeners have allies in this crusade. An aphid's
simplified physical structure makes it easy prey for predators. The
aphid can't move very fast. It walks so slowly, in fact, that
simply washing aphids off with a garden hose each morning can kill
a good many of them. They starve to death before they can climb
back up.

   Insecticidal soaps, which clog the aphid's breathing apparatus
and smother it, are useful, but the spraying must be thorough.
You'll need to repeat the soap spray in a few days, too, because
the last act of a dying aphid is often giving birth.

   Among natural allies, ladybugs and lacewings are the best known
aphid-busters, and both can be purchased for release in the garden
if the native population isn't keeping up. Adult and larval
ladybugs both eat aphids, but only lacewings attack aphids, and
that is only when the lacewings are in the larval stage. If you
import adult lacewings, bear in mind that you won't see results
until the lacewings lay eggs and the eggs hatch.

   Aphids are so plentiful that they are dietary staples for many
other garden inhabitants as well, including spiders, ground
beetles, earwigs and crickets. While it is difficult for me to
regard an earwig as an ally, I am happy for its assistance in aphid
extermination.

   A less visible but highly effective destroyer of aphids is a
tiny native wasp, Aphidius matricariae. You're not likely to spot
this insect in your garden. It's only an eighth of an inch long.
It's related to mud wasps, hornets, yellow jackets and other such
insects that are best steered clear of, but it does not sting
gardeners, only aphids.

   The wasp lays eggs in aphids. When an egg hatches, the young
wasp devours the aphid, leaving nothing but a papery husk of skin,
from which the wasp emerges to fly off in search of more aphids to
slay.

   You'll know you have this miniature benefactor working for you
if you turn over that puckered leaf and spot, among the living
aphids, what look like shiny brown seeds or eggs attached to the
leaf. Those are the mummified remains of aphids, and a sign of
trouble on its way out.
